item.title: Easiest ways to learn something
item.dc:creator: Bryan Whiting
item.description:
The easiest ways to learn how do to something better:

  • do something for the first time
  • Do something 1000 times. You get better over time.
  • Mess up doing something: this is how you realize your initial assumptions were wrong and you overcome beginners luck.
  • Do something fast: You see what you do more efficiently.
  • Do the same thing with new inputs: serve a new customer, try on new shoes for walking.
  • Watch someone do the same thing you‚Äôve done 50 times: you have all the context and you‚Äôre primed to observe new ideas.

This is life experience, it turns out. Doing a lot of stuff on repeat, watching others do it, mess up doing it, or do it slightly differently‚Ä¶

item.title: Scientific method
item.dc:creator: Bryan Whiting
item.description:
I use these seven steps to the scientific method every single day:

  1. What‚Äôs the problem?
  2. Hypothesis: What‚Äôs the believed answer?
  3. Metrics: how do I measure with data?
  4. Methods: how do I test the belief?
  5. Findings: what are the unemotional facts?
  6. Discussion: what are my opinions about the findings? (These are usually more hypotheses.)
  7. Next steps: self explanatory ü§£

It helps me think more clearly when diving into data! Hope it helps.

item.title: Data science structure
item.dc:creator: Bryan Whiting
item.description:
Over my career I‚Äôve thought a lot about ‚Äúwhere should a data scientist sit in an org?‚Äù üëá 5 lessons from what I‚Äôve learned after working in 6 very different companies.

  1. DS under an MBA: maybe okay, probably bound for failure.
  2. DS under the PM: def bound for failure.
  3. DS under the DS: good for the junior in the short term.
  4. DS under Eng: good.
  5. DS under a people manager, but works closely integrated team with a DS-experiences tech lead: best.

Interdisciplinary teams do the best work. It maximizes labor efficiency to have engineers, PMs, and DS‚Äôs working on the same problem but doing different things.

When you federate DS, they don‚Äôt care as much about what they‚Äôre working on. The incentives are off.

When a DS works for a PM the PM will make wild assumptions about what they should do. PMs oversimplify problems and DS find that unsatisfying.

DS reporting to DS means you throw stuff over the fence and the Eng do the real work. And the Eng don‚Äôt capture all the nuance the DS would like to implement.

DS reporting to business types is unfulfilling because DS love technical stuff.

best scenario? Have a DS work in a pod with experienced tech leads. DS reports (HR purposes) to someone outside of the team who can give them guidance but is incapable of micromanaging them.

item.title: 10 steps to optimize anything
item.dc:creator: Bryan Whiting
item.description:
I love-hate goal setting. Here are 10 steps I often fail at in how I try to breakdown and achieve goals, but hey, this is LinkedIn so I‚Äôll share‚Ä¶

  1. Objective: Define your ‚Äúwhere you are going‚Äù and your ‚Äúwhy‚Äù.
  2. Principles: Decide what‚Äôs worth it in how you pursue your where/why.
  3. Key Result: Measure the goal numerically 1-3 ways. Too many is too confusing.
  4. KR-Drivers: Identify the key drivers that affect the goal.
  5. Hypothesize: Use data/intuition to guess what will drive increases in KR-drivers.
  6. Experiment: Try 2 approaches, manipulate the drivers in big or minor ways.
  7. Track: Measure/track/Log what‚Äôs needed to measure if your hypothesis was valid or rejected.
  8. Analyze: make minor tweaks in the drivers and measure statistically significant changes.
  9. Conclude: Which direction will increase your KR. Consider alternate paths if the experiment didn‚Äôt yield good results.
  10. Periodic Evaluation: At a pre-determined cadence (1 wk, 6 wk, quarter), choose if your KR is helping you achieve your objective. 

A few lessons learned as a professional experimenter:

  • Tracking is not the key result. Don‚Äôt confuse them. Too many people  track habits for no reason (I‚Äôm guilty of this 100%)
  • KR‚Äôs have no purpose if you don‚Äôt have an objective. You want 100k ffollowers? 100k revenue? They don‚Äôt mean anything until you know what you‚Äôre going to do with it. More fame/money doesn‚Äôt equal more life satisfaction. Lots of unhappy/depressed rich/famous people.
  • ‚ÄúExperimentation‚Äù early into defining a product should be massive swings. Find the ‚Äúlowest hanging fruit‚Äù, make the biggest changes.
  • Have principles to guide your KR‚Äôs. If you don‚Äôt
  • Have Anti-KR‚Äôs - things you won‚Äôt do. This is the hardest. If you have 10 KR‚Äôs, perhaps KR‚Äôs 2-10 should be all anti-KR‚Äôs. Otherwise, you‚Äôll get distracted on 2 despite you knowing 1 is most important.
  • A rising tide lifts all ships: By improving one KR, you may be sacrificing improving another. But more likely you‚Äôll actually improve all KR‚Äôs, because they‚Äôre usually correlated.

Easy Example: ‚ÄúI want to be healthier‚Äù

  1. Objective: I want more energy to be able to devote it to my kids.

  2. Principles: 

  3. I will not hurt my body by doing unnecessary XYZ

  4. I‚Äôm not going to kill myself. I‚Äôm going to keep this simple.

  5. KR:  (Write down 10, pick the one that will obviate the rest)

  6. Gain 10 lbs of muscle

  7. Eat 100g of protein a day

  8. Sleep 8 hours a day

  9. Meditate 20 minutes a day

  10. KR-drivers for gaining 10 lbs of muscle:

  11. Lift weights

  12. Focus on quads

  13. Focus on upper body

  14. Hypothesize: If I go to the gym for 10 minutes for 28 days and do 30 exercises a day, I‚Äôll gain muscle. 

  15. Experiment: I‚Äôll keep my diet the same - including the popcorn. I‚Äôll focus my mental energy on clearing my calendar and getting out the door to the gym. The ‚Äúcontrol‚Äù experiment is what I‚Äôve done the last 28 days‚Ä¶not worked out ü§£

  16. Track: 

    1. Day 1: I‚Äôll weight myself, write a journal about how I feel. Perhaps ask myself some questions.
    2. Did I go to the gym for 10 minutes? I‚Äôll keep a piece of paper and a pen taped to my mirror or on my nightstand. Checkbox. Don‚Äôt track anything else. This is my one focus right now.

  17. Analyze: on day 28, I‚Äôll weigh myself again. 

  18. Conclude: Did this 28-day challenge change how I felt? Be honest: it might not. Perhaps I can get on my bike, or hike, or do pushups every day instead.

  19. Periodic evaluation: every 2 months I‚Äôll investigate how my energy is.

your goal isn‚Äôt to gain/lose weight. Your goal is to feel better about your health. Your key result is a number on a scale going up/down.

item.dc:creator: Bryan Whiting
item.description:
Solid read: https://markmanson.net/attention-diet Over the last year I had read a few things similar to the points here and went on an ‚Äúlow information‚Äù diet (Tim Ferriss quote?).

  1. I don‚Äôt miss the global news. It only got me angry.

  2. The point of learning something is to take action and create positive change in the world. If I learn about things I don‚Äôt plan to take action on,

  3. if that sounds uneducated, another reason to learn something is to gain empathy and change my perspective. However, the global news is generally biased by the wars for subscriptions between a handful of editors.

  4. Niche news is far more educative. I‚Äôve subscribed to blogs, to specific influencers in my field, etc. I‚Äôve learned things from these people that I can apply that day in my job. I‚Äôm subscribing to things that feed my career.

  5. long form content is far better way to understand current events. If you want to understand the state of the world, read a book on it. Most major geopolitical events are insanely complicated and cannot be surmised in 126 characters. Read a few books on the things you care about.

  6. there‚Äôs so much thought put into even a low quality book. Think about it: most books get reviewed by editors in the very least. They probably get read once or twice at least by the original authors. So what would be a better time for your energy - a low quality book or a set of posts on LinkedIn likely generated by ChatGPT or Jasper.ai? If a low quality book > than a tweet, surely 30 min a day of a high quality book (easy to find) is worth more than most low quality content.

  7. I broke my iPhone in 2020 and waited 45 days for a replacement. But it wasn‚Äôt fully broken - the screen was hopelessly shattered on the bottom half where typing is required. So I kept it in my drawer and only used it when I needed to. The risk of using it? Getting a shard of glass stuck in my finger. I wish I still had that to some degree because it forced me to be focused. I realized very few people texted me anything urgent that couldn‚Äôt wait a few days. I could still call people with Siri, but nobody called. We‚Äôre optimized to be addicted. That‚Äôs literally the goal of these phones and the apps on them. That‚Äôs not a bad thing. It‚Äôs just not in our best interest.

  8. I tried using a junk $40 replacement phone I found in my closet while waiting those 45 days to get my iPhone replacement. The phone was from 2015 when I got married - it was a teaser phone from the cell company. It probably downloaded at 2 mbp/s. Any time I clicked a link I had to wait 15-20 seconds for the page to load.

I was amazed. I was shocked this piece of junk actually could take notes. Could email. Could browse the internet. But I also learned not to click on things unless it was worth 30 seconds of my time.

How do I spend my time now? Not wisely enough. A lot of things should be done on a computer. Most things should be planned. Few things are urgent. Fewer are essential.

item.title: A Treatise on Agency and Goals
item.dc:creator: Bryan Whiting
item.description:
I may have ADHD to some degree, I‚Äôm not sure. These thoughts came to me today when considering my side business.

A treatise on desire, uncertainty, commitment, and execution toward a goal.

Descartes proposed that if you pick a direction and walk in a straight line you‚Äôll eventually leave the forest. This assumes you want to leave the forest.

A desire is a persistent yearning. Desires take root and, when nurtured, become reality.

An achieved desire is a blend of hope, faith, and charity. A hope (goal) is the edge of the forest. Walking is faith (belief + action). Charity is long suffering and persistence - the ability to maintain hope and faith.

A hope is envisioned or observed. If observed, there is believed certainty in achievement, with uncertainty in the path. An envisioned hope has uncertainty in both the path and the outcome. You might die trying. Envisioned hopes are impossible only when the path is not made clear. Thought makes the path clear.

A clear path is a plan. A plan is a sequence of informed choices and actions leading towards a goal, a consequence. A causal effect. Reconnaissance is the finite time and energy spent collecting information. Reason invites spending time and energy proportional to the cost or impact of the plan and goal. Judgment determines which choices and actions are taken.

Commitment is recognizing many roads lead to Rome, and only one of them can be walked to actually get there.

Luck is unknown things. Some things could have been known with more reconnaissance. Other things could never have been known or anticipated. Luck either enables or disables the path. Luck happens post plan, post deliberation. It‚Äôs the unknown distance between you and the forest‚Äôs edge. Hindsight bias is the present mind‚Äôs ability to mistakenly believe uncertainty was always certain. ‚ÄúI should have known‚Äù is an oxymoron.

Enabling luck makes possible the goal. Disabling luck makes difficult the goal, perhaps impossible. Impossible is usually a state of mind or the laws of physics, but usually never both.

Tilt is the mist of blindness caused by the presence of luck. Tilt distracts from information and commitment, a bias caused by observed outcomes that were previously uncertain.

Commitment is time and energy. Time is measured by rotations of the earth or attempts made. Energy is measured by willingness to roll the dice again.

Commitment is also reconnaissance. More actions, more information. Ignorance is choosing not to see the information. Stubbornness is seeing it, and maintaining the status quo for thrill of ego. Humility is hunger for more information.

Uncertainty invites fear and worry. Perceived time spent amplifies fear and worry. Uncertainty in the path. Uncertainty in the destination, etc.

A plan is the process of committing to something knowing that hindsight bias creeps in with each step. The plan mitigates the drag of hindsight bias.

Fear and anxiety are compounded when accomplishment doesn‚Äôt happen within perceived time. Human nature is to lose all track of time when in a task, so time should be planned for. Time to evaluate the plan and assess new information should also be decided in the plan.

Commitment to the plan is a recognition of the infallibility of human emotion. Judgment is evaluating if the plan could be improved, and the plan includes time/effort-base checkpoints for evaluation. Commitment is the recognition that, while the direction you‚Äôre heading may not be the right one, (shortest path between you and the edge of the forest which you can‚Äôt know at onset), walkikg straight is better than circling from changing direction multiple times. Straight lines are incapable of not exiting. Circles may exit but are capable of not exiting.

If new information overrides understood information at the time of the plan, and changes the decision that would have been made given the circumstances at the time of the plan, then wisdom and humility is the ability to change direction despite how many miles walked (sunk cost).

Walking in a straight line in business is ‚Äúwalking in accordance to the plan‚Äù. The time spent deliberating the plan should be proportional to the costs and benefits of the action, which requires judgment. Inspiration is praying that God will guide you and enable your plan.

Arrogance is believing you have infinite energy and time. Optimism is appreciating that any mile walked strengthens your legs, that the direction you chose may not match the imagined ideal. Self awareness is appreciating that the human mind is capable of any imagination, and few imaginations consider accurately all costs or benefits of reality. Imaginations are powerful, but can cause circling, and are most powerful during the plan. After the plan, use imagination to accomplish it. Before the plan, use imagination to design it. But don‚Äôt use imagination during the plan to redesign it, I.e, avoid circling.

Action gets stuff done.

item.title: My Advice for New Career People
item.dc:creator: Bryan Whiting
item.description:
The keys for me for job satisfaction are now pretty basic:

  • Is my manager supportive and someone I like spending time with?
  • Is the work continuously interesting? Will I develop skills that are likely to bring interesting opportunities in the future?
  • Is there incentive alignment between what I offer and what the company needs?

This blog post will attempt to describe my thoughts on what makes for a fulfilling career. It‚Äôs a hard question. Maybe something in here is valuable as you search for your ‚Äúideal‚Äù career.

Likely useless career advice

Now for a stream of consciousness about corporate employment‚Ä¶

Some say a job should help you 1) earn or 2) learn and if neither then leave. But that framework doesn‚Äôt really work because you can learn anything anywhere.

Knowledge is accretive. As I look back on jobs I didn‚Äôt love, I still learned things. I wasn‚Äôt a fan of the type of consulting I was doing 10 years ago, but I‚Äôve now started a consulting firm and having had that experience is helpful. So it‚Äôs all kind of gray. I didn‚Äôt like pulling weeds as a kid but I‚Äôm now pulling weeds as a homeowner so yea, I‚Äôm glad I know how to do that.

what is life anyway?

Per Guide to Decision Making, ‚Äúresulting‚Äù may apply if you say you made a good decision because you enjoyed a job. By the same token you made a bad decision because you didn‚Äôt enjoy the job.

The reality is that ‚Äúall or nothing thinking‚Äù is more of a cognitive bias, per The Coddling of the American Mind and The Worry Cure. And so, you‚Äôre going to learn things as long as you‚Äôre remotely interested in learning things. Whether they satisfy your Working Genius is another matter.

I want my ‚Äúdream‚Äù job though

Can you land your dream job? Or is it a myth? 30-40% of first time marriages end in divorce. And not all of the remaining 70-60% are blissfully happy either. But many of those 70% ARE blissfully happy. Or they will be. Or they were and they will be again maybe or something‚Ä¶

Marriage and work are similar: they‚Äôre a type of relationship.

Happiness in a relationship takes both people being committed to the happiness of the other. One sided relationships eventually crumble. But if both people remain committed to the other‚Äôs happiness, and other certain caveats‚Ä¶, the marriage will prove valuable to both for their whole lives.

Professional and Life happiness

Happiness to me comes in two forms: doing the best I can with the circumstances I have (the cards I‚Äôve been dealt) and choosing environments that are healthy (the game that gives me the cards).

It‚Äôs about 1) what you‚Äôre doing and 2) the environment and context you‚Äôre doing it in.

This is life. Some games are fun to me. Others less fun by definition. But any game may be better than no game. Unless the game involves a high risk of me breaking my spine. Nuance.

Point is: it takes a long while to find what environments you thrive in. Any company can offer just one or potentially many environments depending on their size or the role.

So if you don‚Äôt know what you‚Äôre interested in, you must explore. You try.

Finding the best environment

First on the environment.

Jane Austen is better at this than me. Take all those sisters in Pride and Prejudice who have varying views on love and stability. Some sisters believe in true love. Others think it‚Äôs a myth and instead choose financial stability. Of course true love wins in the end.

I suppose work is very similar: you‚Äôre going to get out of it what you believe is possible. After all: you work with and for people.

It will take time and risks to figure out what environments you thrive in, kind of like dating. The interview is part of the process. Bring in a company is another part. Talking to friends in other companies is a third part. Thinking grass is greener is a fourth part, and so forth. That‚Äôs life.

Your needs also change in your career. As you change, your preferences change. It‚Äôs up to you to learn how to match your preferences with your environments, and how to accommodate your preferences within your environments.

If you don‚Äôt like your roommate, you can leave early or wait till your contract expires or etc etc. or you can try to work it out and get to know your roommate. All are options. Which you choose is up to you. In the end, a good environment takes two. But it also takes one to instigate change for the better for both. Reciprocity.

Experiment Your Way to a Happy Career

Then there‚Äôs the thing you‚Äôre doing.

You can ‚Äútry‚Äù anything by doing it yourself. Do you want to be a teacher? Go try to volunteer teaching. Do you want to be a coder? Spend 20 hours trying to build an app. Do you want to be a doctor? Volunteer with doctors.

Four ways of learning what you like emerge. The quality of the information is ordered top to bottom while the amount of time it takes to get that information is bottom to top:

  • Reading about an industry or job is kind of helpful.
  • Talking to people in the field is more helpful.
  • Following and shadowing those people is even more useful.
  • But actually doing the work is the only way to really know.

You can read about 50 jobs to see what piques your interest and help you learn what‚Äôs out there. Next, you can increase the chance of pursuing a job you like by trying to do it without actually having to get the job.

You can get a pretty good sense by doing little projects similar to what the real work is going to be.

Don‚Äôt Not Try Something Because of a Dumb Reason

A lot of people think they shouldn‚Äôt do something because they‚Äôre not good enough. Even professionals. (Tiger Woods just had his worst round of his life, but I‚Äôm guessing he‚Äôs still better than you.)

Or they think they shouldn‚Äôt try something because they‚Äôre not yet credentialed. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt try this at home kids‚Äù. It‚Äôs what we‚Äôre taught.

And that‚Äôs kind of the great myth: the myth of titles and credentials. That you need to be experienced at something to be able to do that thing. But that‚Äôs a lie. Instead, you should only pursue the credential if it offers you something you can‚Äôt otherwise get (due to red tape). And until you get the credential, you‚Äôre just spending a few hours every day learning stuff and maybe passing an exam at the end. So if you ignore the exam, what‚Äôs stopping you from just picking up the activities today you may find rewarding?

I once spent a single week shadowing dentists in an open room in Honduras. I was a Spanish translator for these American dentists that came through. I felt pretty confident by the end that I could probably do one of the fillings just because it really wasn‚Äôt that complicated. And the dentists told me so. Once you look at 100 cavities in a mouth it‚Äôs not hard to spot them. This was the easiest way to de-myth this job: watching and observing.

It was actually really boring. Once you‚Äôve seen 100 cavities you‚Äôve seen them all I think. Glad I figured that out quickly! But I know there‚Äôs someone out there that disagrees with me and I‚Äôm glad they‚Äôll be drilling my teeth and not me.

90% of most people‚Äôs jobs could be taught via apprenticeship, like the good old days. Today‚Äôs world of credentials makes people think they‚Äôre incapable of doing a pretty simple task: putting a tool into someone‚Äôs tooth. But before you invest 8 years of your life in dental school, why not go be a dental hygienist for 1 year? Instead of doing a coding bootcamp, why not just code in your basement for a month after hours? This is the way to find what you like.

Whether you enjoy doing that thing that created value for people can only be discovered by doing it.

People Hire you Because you offer a Service or Value. Period.

Your real job is to create value for people. It‚Äôs not a title. It‚Äôs not a credential. It‚Äôs not mandated or necessary in society. And if you were born 100 years before today or 100 years after the job may not exist. So think about opportunities in this way.

A healthier way to thinking about corporate life is: what creates value? Is there a reasonable exchange of goods for my offering?

I‚Äôm capable of many offerings. But they‚Äôre hiring for one offering. That‚Äôs life.

If I were selling apricots, and someone was offering me peanuts, would I exchange my apricots for their peanuts? Well, if we were the only two people sure.

But maybe I feel like I can get some avocados for my apricots. So can I find an avocado dealer? Do they even like apricots? Do they already have enough apricots? And if yes to all the above, are they even in the mood to exchange for apricots today? Lastly, do they like me?

Getting a job is more of a negotiation than anything. And everything in work is a negotiation. Read Never Split the Difference and that becomes quite apparent. Work is nothing fancy. It‚Äôs not a title. It‚Äôs not a degree. It‚Äôs just doing little activities.

And after you‚Äôve 1000 similar activities you‚Äôre soon labeled a data scientist or a farmer. And if you circled the right boxes on an exam and got a piece of paper you‚Äôre now a doctor/dentist. But the paper or the title don‚Äôt make you good at that thing. My point: create value, not titles.

In Sum

So yes. I‚Äôve gone on a rant here. But hey this is my blog. I‚Äôm trying to talk about the deeper issues at how to choose a profession or a company within that profession. I‚Äôm trying to break away from the titles and credentials that blind our thinking away from the more important questions of ‚Äúwhat activities bring me joy‚Äù and ‚Äúhow will I know it?‚Äù And ‚Äúwill someone pay me for doing this activity?‚Äù And ‚Äúhow do I find an environment of people that will enable me to do valuable activities and make it a pleasant place to work?‚Äù (PS, some say to not work for Elon Musk‚Ä¶unless you enjoy his working style.)

Long story short: make sure the company hiring you actually needs your skills to run their business. Strive to find better opportunities by putting yourself out there and trying new things. And find people you like working with. All the rest is just a bonus.

The most dangerous thing is to get all those good things on your first job because then you try to self actualize per Maslov‚Äôs hierarchy of needs. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt it always seem to go That you don‚Äôt know what you got ‚Äôtil it‚Äôs gone?‚Äù (Lyrics) So if you get a ‚Äúbad‚Äù job just know it‚Äôs part of the process and one day 10 years from now you‚Äôll probably be grateful you had that job anyway.

If I didn‚Äôt actually answer your questions that‚Äôs because some questions are a perennial debate. Some popular people hate the idea of work-life balance, some embrace it. Go figure. And keep searching to find someone who sees work and career the same way you do, because there are millions of jobs in the work. Hundreds of millions.

Books to read

It helps to get perspective when choosing where you want to work.

  • How to Decide: Simple Tools for Making Better Choices - have a decision framework
  • The 6 Types of Working Genius - understand who you are.
  • Overcoming the Five Dysfunctions of a Team - it helps to recognize a good company by first understanding a bad company.
  • The Old Man and the Sea - a job is a job at the end of the day. It‚Äôs just fishing.

Practical Questions

Things I‚Äôd think about in your shoes:

  • what loosely sounds interesting? Who perhaps knows someone with that type of role? How do I get 15 min with that person, or a quick email? (Use 6 degrees of separation to your advantage)
  • do I have an ideal salary? What‚Äôs realistic? (Levels.fyi, don‚Äôt over or undersell yourself. Figure out market rates and if your job will support your desired lifestyle in a location)
  • what‚Äôs the entry level job that gets me some experience 50% in the right direction that I‚Äôm interested in?
  • where will I learn?
  • Does this company offer flexibility to try new things?

Sometimes job searching is helped by thinking by contrast:

  • what can someone not pay me $500k per year to do? $300k? $100k? (Nobody could pay me $500k to be an investment banker and work 100 hour weeks. Maybe they could pay me $2M and I‚Äôd do it for 2 years ya know? But $500 isn‚Äôt enough.)

As you‚Äôre interviewing:

  • what incentivizes people on a daily basis?
  • will this job be around in 2 years? Why? Why not? Why might they fire me in 6 months for things 100% outside of my control? (Recessions, business strategy shifts, etc)
  • how essential is my skillset to what they do?
  • what relationship do people have with my would-be manager?

Questions to potentially ask your hiring manager:

  • How do you see me fitting into this role?
  • Why might this role not be a good fit for me?
  • Who‚Äôs the highest ranking person who‚Äôs quit or been fired recently and why?
  • How do you define success for this role?

Questions to ask your peers you‚Äôre interviewing with:

  • describe your relationship with your manager?
  • describe the communication patterns of the team?
  • describe how decisions are made? What‚Äôs a recent decision that was made? describe your role in how the team made that decision?

item.dc:creator: Bryan Whiting
item.description:
How do I add an iCloud account to iOS Outlook without it being a public calendar?

It was easy to add any gmail accounts but I didn‚Äôt know how to add my iCloud calendar to iOS Outlook. Part of the issue is my iCloud account is actually my gmail email address so I can‚Äôt sign in with this or it‚Äôll load my gmail calendar.

Solution:

  • go to iOS settings > iCloud > get your @icloud.com name. If you use your gmail account for iCloud there‚Äôs still this @icloud account.
  • Attempt to log into iOS Outlook calendar. Apple will then make you create an app-specific password for iOS Outlook
  • Use this password.

Done. Pain solved.

item.title: Book Summaries
item.dc:creator: Bryan Whiting
item.description:
Beyond Band of Brothers: The War Memoirs of Major Dick Winters

Leadership from the bayonette. 10 points of leadership by dick winters.

  1. Strive to be a leader of character, competence, and courage.
  2. Lead from the front. Say, ‚ÄúFollow me!‚Äù and then lead the way.
  3. Stay in top physical shape‚Äîphysical stamina is the root of mental toughness.
  4. Develop your team. If you know your people, are fair in setting realistic goals and expectations, and lead by example, you will develop teamwork.
  5. Delegate responsibility to your subordinates and let them do their jobs. You can‚Äôt do a good job if you don‚Äôt have a chance to use your imagination or your creativity.
  6. Anticipate problems and prepare to overcome obstacles. Don‚Äôt wait until you get to the top of the ridge and then make up your mind.
  7. Remain humble. Don‚Äôt worry about who receives the credit. Never let power or authority go to your head.
  8. Take a moment of self-reflection. Look at yourself in the mirror every night and ask yourself if you did your best.
  9. True satisfaction comes from getting the job done. The key to a successful leader is to earn respect‚Äînot because of rank or position, but because you are a leader of character.
  10. Hang tough!‚ÄîNever, ever give up.

item.dc:creator: Bryan Whiting
item.description:
‚ÄúThis is the moment I‚Äôve been waiting for‚Äù‚Ä¶until it wasn‚Äôt.

Several years ago as a budding data scientist I got excited by using a massive compute cluster. This is it. This is when I get to do Big Data Science, baby!

A few thousand dollars later, I realized my hundred-dollar-an-hour cluster wasn‚Äôt doing the thing I hired it to do.

My patient manager David Mantilla ssh‚Äôd into my cluster and discovered that out of the 64 cores I paid for, I was using only 1.

A good manager goes a long way. He just laughed as I stared in horror at my gross misconduct.

Be kind to the noobs. Because you still are one in many ways‚Ä¶
